text:
Hi. I'm Jennifer from English with
Jennifer, and I'd like to share a lesson

to help you learn English vocabulary and
understand American culture a little better.

Thanksgiving is a time when we
gather with family.

Sadly, my family is so spread out that we
can't easily gather for holidays.

My relatives don't just live in different
towns or even different states; they live

in different countries. Thankfully, I have
some things in my home that make me feel

closer to family. For example, I have
serving dishes from my grandmother.

Like this one and this one. When I see
them and use them, I think of all the

Thanksgiving dinners we had with family
around the table. My extended family is quite large.

Do you know what I mean by
extended family? In this lesson, we'll go

beyond basic family vocabulary and we'll
talk about different branches on your
family tree.

When you're a kid, your immediate family
is your parents and your siblings.

Some call this the nuclear family. I think
sometimes the words are interchangeable.
Nuclear family. Immediate family. But what I understand is that the nuclear family

is under one roof. The household of a
nuclear family consists of the parents
and the children. My concept of immediate family is a bit bigger.
As adults many of us

get married and have children. You
could say that my nuclear family now is

my husband and our children.
But when I think of immediate family,

I still include my parents and my brothers.
Does that make sense?

But those relatives are not necessarily
considered immediate family for my children.

For them, their immediate family
is me, my husband, their father, and each other. Get it?
You'll hear the term "immediate family" in the context of rules

and policies. For example, at a hospital, a
very sick patient would be allowed to

receive visits only from immediate
family. And at work, you would be allowed

to take off a certain number of days for
a family emergency. That's a kind of
emergency that concerns immediate family, not some distant cousin.
Extended family refers to relatives outside the nuclear family: grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins.

All those more distant branches on your
family tree are part of your extended family.
Did you know your great-grandparents? Maybe you're fortunate enough
to still have them around today.
I knew my great-grandmother. She was my grandfather's mother, and she came to the U.S.
from Hungary. She married my great-grandfather who came from Serbia.
My great-grandparents on my grandmother's side were from Poland, and they didn't
live long for me to meet them. Obviously, I didn't

have the chance to meet my
great-great-grandparents.

I met my paternal grandparents, my
father's parents, because they visited us
from the Philippines when I was a child.

Note how we can use these phrases to
clarify which part of the family tree

were referring to: on my mother's side, on
my father's side, my maternal grandparents,
my paternal grandparents.

Now this is where it gets a little
confusing. Who is the sister of your grandmother or grandfather?
That's your great-aunt. Some say grandaunt,

but I don't hear that too much. I
knew at least two of my great-aunts on

my mother's side. My grandmother's
brother needed regular care, so he lived
with my grandparents. Who was he to me? He was my great-uncle, and I was his grandniece.

My brothers were his grandnephews.
You'll also hear "great-niece" and "great-nephew."

Same thing. Just remember that we
use "great" to indicate that we're one

generation removed from that person. We
add on another "great" for each generation.

Can you name your great-great
grandparents? Do you know how I called my relatives

in childhood? Forms of address
vary from family to family, especially in

intercultural marriages. I called my
grandparents on my mother's side Grandma
and Grandpap. I called my grandparents on my father's side Lola and Lolo.

My -uncle was Uncle Jim. My great-aunt
was Aunt Kazia. And note how I said "aunt."

In American English. you can say /ænt/ or
/ɑnt/. I just happened to say /ænt/. My Aunt Kazia.
My children call my husband's mother Babushka.

Their grandmother is in Russia. What do
you call your grandparents?
How do you address aunts and uncles?
My father immigrated from the Philippines, so I

didn't get to know his side of the
family too well. I did get the chance to

meet most of his sisters. They were and
are my aunts. On my mother's side, I

didn't have any aunts or uncles because
she was an only child. But my grandmother

came from a very large family, and her
siblings had children, so my mother and I
had lots of cousins growing up.
A first cousin is the child of an aunt or an uncle.
Second cousins share great-grandparents. Think about that for a moment.

My grandmother had one child, my
mother. My grandmother's sister, my Aunt Kazia

also had children. Those children
were first cousins to my mother.

Their children and I share a set of
great-grandparents, so we're second cousins.

At least, that's how I understand
it. When it gets really confusing, we just

call people cousins. I have a lot of
cousins back in Pennsylvania, my home state.

You can get into third cousins
when you start talking about children of

second cousins, but if it gets too
confusing, then just call people cousins

or simply family. You can call relatives
family. You're related. They're part of

your extended family. When we can't
remember exactly how we're related, we

sometimes refer to someone as a distant
cousin. You know that you're related by blood.

Sometimes you'll hear once removed
or twice removed. This refers to how far

apart you are in generations. My mother's
first cousin and I became quite close.
She is my first cousin once removed. For my children, she is

their first cousin twice removed. They
simply think of her as a cousin.
It's simpler that way. Let's not forget about in-laws. When you get married, you marry into another family.
My husband's parents are my in-laws. My mother-in-law and

father-in-law were able to attend our
wedding because we got married in Russia.

My husband has a sister. She is my
sister-in-law, and my brothers became my
husband's brothers-in-law.
Note these plural forms: mothers-in-law,
fathers-in-law, sisters-in-law, brothers-in-law.
But to talk about the mother and father of your spouse, you can simply say "in-laws." For example,
"We're spending Thanksgiving with my in-laws." Or "My in-laws are visiting this weekend."

In modern society, we have different kinds
of families. Second and third marriages

are fairly common, so we have blended
families. That's when two families become one.

A couple gets married, and they bring
with them children from a previous marriage.
The ex-husband or ex-wife are no longer

immediate family to the person who got
remarried. In a blended family or in a
second marriage, we can talk about stepparents and stepchildren, stepmother

stepfather, stepsister, stepbrother. When
you think about parents and siblings and

cousins of a stepmother or stepfather, it
gets a little confusing. You can explain

that someone isn't a blood relation.
They're not a blood relative, but they're

still family. You can be related by birth
or by marriage. The funny thing is that

we can be very close to someone who
isn't a blood relative,
but they're like family. We say, "She's like a sister to me."  "I consider him family."

Here are a couple more words you
need to know. What do we call two
children who share only one parent?
They're half-brothers and half-sisters.

For fun and for practice, talk about your
family. See how many people you can name

on your family tree. Use vocabulary from
this lesson.
Here's a quick quiz you can answer in the comments.
Who is your mother's new husband?
Who is your grandmother's brother?
Who is your aunt's son?
Who is your wife's sister?
Who is the son of your father and stepmother?
Who is your great uncle's granddaughter?
What's a blended family?
Name two different ways people can be related.

That's all for now. I hope you found this
lesson useful and interesting.
Please like and share the video with others learning English.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me and gain more practice on
Facebook and Twitter. I also have new

videos on Instagram. If you haven't
already, subscribe to my channel so you

get notification of every new video I
upload to YouTube.
